EDITORIAL.
HE NEWS-LETTER wishes on behalf of the students to thank the Lacrosse
Team of 1902 for their generous offer. Such spirit is surely an answer
to the mistaken theory that spirit is wanting at Hopkins. The class
teams of last year were recognized as one of the reasons for the successful lacrosse year. They not only aroused interest but developed
material. Without interest and a well-trained scrub a team is seriously
handicapped. Let us hope that 1902's enthusiasm will be well repaid in the shape of another
championship team in 1907!

HE gentle reader will notice in this issue two letters. One is the official
statement of the Board of Governors of the Athletic Association in regard to baseball and undergraduate football; the other a letter from Mr.
Thomas Campbell apropos of baseball. Mr. Campbell's letter is equally
authorative. THE NEWS-LETTER believes there should be a baseball
team if it is possible. Also it believes there should be no criticism of
the J. H. U. A. A., in its attitude on baseball up to this time, it should
be recognized that no team can be run without money. But it seems to
THE NEWS-LETTER that money is the only consideration. It is to be
hoped that the undergraduate team idea will not be overworked. It has many advantages but
the fact must ever be remembered that the graduate and medical departments have just as good
a right on the teams (other things being equal) as the undergraduates. As a member of the
Athletic Board has said, "the undergraduate idea can easily he run into the ground."
There is no cause for excited words over the baseball situation; if there is need

S we have said before in a previous issue, it is not exactly our intention
to pull up this or that skeleton which may lurk around the University,
or to continually point the finger of shame at the various activities which
go to make up the daily life of the institution, but rather do we intend
to furnish a fair statement of the consensus of opinion of the under'graduate body and at the same time to bring out a really interesting
paper which will count for much in the raising of much lowered moral
standards. "But, 'now to business;' said Sue."
The recent controversy which has arisen among the students as to
the recognition of the baseball team has brought to our mind a question concerning the Athletic Board, that is, what does the Athletic Board really represent? One
hears on all sides statements as to the partiality of the board as to the unfairness and so on
until one wonders how the board ever were elected.

When we acknowledge their election the

question arises as to what consensus of opinion do they follow. Among the list of members
we see that there are senior delegates, junior delegates and a freshman delegate but as far as
can be seen the only thing necessary for their election is that they belong to their respective
classes. Do they then necessarily represent the members of their class. According to the
present system of election we do not think so. The delegates are elected by the members of
the University in toto and it matters little if the class which the delegate is going to represent
is for or against the one elected. Consequently the delegates of the various classes do not in
any way represent the opinions of their classes and are in no way bound to carry out any of
the plans which that class may see fit to suggest. To my mind this mode of procedure is not
exactly just to say the least.
A better plan might be to have the various classes elect their own delegates separately
and have it understood that these delegates are to follow the expression of opinion of that
class. How far it would be beneficial to carry this out is a question which we will not undertake to state here.
It is obviously necessary that something must be done in this direction on account of
the hammering that the Athletic Board has been receiving in the last two years. Last year
on account of the track team and this year on account of this baseball question. While we
know that there will always be complainers, would it not be better to do something to hush
this continual knocking than to let things run on as they are? It would be better in our
opinion to have these delegates elected at the same time as the other officers of the class.

There was once a course in the University
called History 7, if there had not been this
story would not have been written. By some
chance the instructor of this course was
named Blinkensop, Ph. D. His real name
was Holy Blinky. By chance, in the guise of
a hurried and worried advisor, my friend
Warren Caruthers Carteret took this course.
Perhaps it was not chance, but assuredly it
was not by design that "Carrie" Carderet
flunked the Christmas examination in History
7. "Hence," as my friend 'Hooley" puts
it, "the trade winds."
Now it is remarkable how many people
liked "Carrie Carteret. Dogs, men and girls
had him for their friend and he had them. It
may be doubted whether even the instructors
did not in the bottom of their hearts, really
rejoice in his atmosphere. Even little crabbed
Guerber, the instructor in German 2, was
cheered when "Carrie" politely uncovered to
him.
It was true that Carruthers did flunk, but
it as he said was probably because Blinkensop
did not approve of tweeds and cigarettes.
"And now," said Carteret, "I will thank any
one for a simple paper cigarrette whilst I regale myself (and possibly you) with the tale
of the 'voyage de M. Blinkensop.'"
"It seems," continued Carteret, "that at
one time my friend Blinky, Ph. D.. was
selected as the historian of an expedition to

the West Indies. No. I don't know what
the expedition was about, nor why the devil
he was selected. But I do want you to understand that Edmund Thensaurochryson
ichochrysides Blinkensop is a most religious,
careful, conscientious, scrupulous person, and
that is exactly why I didn't get through History 7.
"Now on this expedition were, I should
say, a very jolly set, even if they were doctors
of philosophy, and on arriving in port at some
foolish island, which belongs to the British
they paid their respects to the governor, who
was lonesome in his solemnity, which consisted of niggers. And after consuming many
cooling drinks,(They grow mint on those
islands, don't they? If they don't I wont
patronize them.) they, as I was about to say,
before I interrupted myself, were invited to a
large luncheon the following day, which I
think was perfectly sweet of the governor. I
will thank anyone for another cigarette.
"Yes, sir! They were all invited to this
party, every man on board, including Holy
Blinky. Well, naturally, they all put on their
fine apparel and Blinky primped longer than
the rest. So the men on deck, all glorious
with white flannel and hat bands, waited for
Blinky. Finally Blinky appeared in a frock
coat, red tie, duck trousers, a yachting cap.
It was a great thing, he thought, to be entertained by the representive of the British.

LIONET.
I.
Day-time, or night? nay, love, I hardly know,
With me the clouds have fallen now so low
I cannot tell if night or day be here;
All that I know is that the hours do go.
Then, must I leave the sun and pass away?
Ah, will you in the earth my body lay?
All the fair flowers and forests I must leave,
All the bright beauties of the dazziing day?
Outside, the fields are sunny and the trees
Rustle melodiously amidst the breeze,
The air is filled with song of happy birds
And droning hum of honey-bearing bees.
IV.
And here, within this chamber, at my side
Art thou, my love, my fair one, 0 my bride!
You must I leave, 0 worser fate by far
And my one comfort is "All men have died."
V. .
The darkness closes in, night comes apace,
Now would I give all hope of Heaven's grace,
All future joys and all life divine,
For one lost lingering look upon thy face.
VI•
The shadow wraps me round and all is dark;—
I see, I feel. I hear not.—Nay, but hark!
My inner conscience tells me that without
Carrols with joyous note the morning lark!

BASEBALL.
December 8, 1906.
To the Editor of the News-Letter:
DEAR SIR.—I was delighted to read, in
your last issue, an article advocating the recognition of the baseball team for this year. This,
coming from a member of last year's team,
shows that the spiritfor baseball has not entirely succumbed, while at the same time it
proves that those who took part in the game
and know most about the matter are eager for
the maintenance of the team, and fully aware
of the fact that it is not only possible to have
one, but that it is the best thing and the only
thing to do.
There are two reasons given for not recognizing the team—namely, lack of interest and
lack of funds.
For anyone to say that there is a lack of interest is as absurd as it would be immaterial
if it were a fact. If there's no interest—make
it. Anyone who was present at the Lehigh
game last year would have been a poor interpreter of human actions if he should not have
seen that the fellows were with the team, and
crazy for victory and delighted when it came.
To tell the truth, I believe there was more interest shown at that game than at any Lacrosse game last year, with the possible exception of;the Swarthmore game, for which I cannot speak as I was not fortunate enough to be
present, being at the time at Charlottesville
where we enjoyed another glorious victory.
But whatever might have been the real feeling in the matter, the fact remains that there
were as many fellows present at the baseball
games, and as much rooting, if not more,
than at the Lacrosse games.
Someone might say: "Oh, yes, when we
have a team, the fellows come out to see the
games, but they are not interested enough to
try for the team, etc., etc." All of which is
again absurd, and contrary to fact. We had
something like fifteen or twenty candidates
last year. Some of these, it is true, were not
up to the standard, but the fact remains that
they had the spirit to come out. What's more,
at least half the fellows are back again, and
there are other good men who said they would
come out this year. All that is needed now,
is a manager to arrange a schedule and to
drum up players, but he's needed immediately.

The objection that there are not enough
funds to run a baseball team together with the
other teams, of course is a different matter,
and can best be decided by the Athletic Board—
for they know what money they have and for
what it is to be spent.
Still, I think if they make a careful study
of the thing they will come to the conclusion
that a baseball team can easily be recognized
and backed financially. To back up this
statement we have only to look at last years
record of expenses, etc.
The appropriation for baseball last year was
$225. Their actual expenses—over gate receipts, etc.—was about $157. This means
that the team spent only $157 of the appropriation, i. e. $70 less than was authorized.
If this could be done last year, it can be
done this year. In fact, I think the team will
have fewer expenses this year than last. Last
year we had to buy suits which cost about $42;
we had to buy a mitt which cost $5. This is
$47 which will not have to be spent this year.
But this is not all—for last year we played St.
John's in Baltimore—or rather scheduled the
game there. This year we would have to
play at Annapolis, and would receive $30
guarantee which would more than pay expenses. We could get $40 from Navy, which
much more than pays expenses. West Point
gave us $125 last year, which paid expenses
all but about $10. They were very much
pleased with the game, and asked us to be
sure to come again. I'm certain they would
give a guarantee to cover expenses this year.
University of Virginia gave a guarantee which
paid expenses all but 8 cents.
Certainly, from these few facts it is plain
that the financial difficulty is more of a myth
than a reality. Nor does the fact that the

morning. The only other game we had
scheduled at home was the St. John's game
which more than paid expenses by over $80,
and which would have paid still more had not
the storm come up, and kept the people away.
I don't want to be "butting in" on anything that is none of my business, but as I am
very much interested in the team, and as I

know the facts of the case, I thought it would
be worth while acquainting the fellows with
the same. While I think the Athletic Board
has done what it deems best, I think also that
they acted too hastily in abandoning the team,
and most inexcusably slow in electing another
manager. They evidently have an erroneous
idea of the amount of interest in the game at
J. H. U., and they over-estimate the expense
of running the team.
What would be the result if someone should
suggest that we drop Lacrosse? There's not
one of us who would not fight to the last ditch
to maintain the game. Its our game. In
Lacrosse we're "it." Just so will we fight
for baseball. It's the game of America—the
game of all colleges. And, while we have
obtained more glory in Lacrosse, we feel that
the baseball team has done, taking everything

licked.

Hopkins, the game which most men, who
have played all the games and know them,
recognize as, not only one of the most open
and beautiful games to watch, but, with the
possible exception of tennis, as the cleanest
and most sportsmanlike game we have.

To the Editor of the News-Letter:
DEAR SIR —There has been a great deal of
discussion about the action of the Athletic
Board in regard to the baseball and football
teams and it was deemed advisable than an
explanation should be made.

team.
2nd—There was not sufficient interest mani-

In explantion of the first reason let me give
a few figures.
There is placed in the hands of the Athletic
Board each year by the University about $800.
This is usually divided among the four
teams of football, track, lacrosse and baseball
by appropriations of $200 to each team.
Last year however, the football team had a
deficit of $79 extra of their appropriation but
this was covered by the fact that the track
team turned back $76 to the treasury since
they made $242 at the meet held in the
Armory and the lacrosse team turned back
$79 owing to the gain of $321 from the
Swarthmore game.
The. baseball team, thanks to the excellent
management of Mr. Cambell turned back
$59. So all was well.
This year the football was given their usual
appropriation of $200 and besides that they
have a deficit of nearly $400. The lacrosse
team will in all probability not have as successful a season as last year since the Swarthmore game will be played out of town and the
$321 made at that game will not be forthcoming this year. This means that most likely
the lacrosse team will need more money than
their $200 appropriation.
The track team so far, has been unable to
secure the Armory for a meet and that means
that $242 made last year at the Armory games
will be cut off from the track team this year.
If the Armory is secured one-half the gain
goes to the Homewood. This team will most
assuredly need more than $200.
Now if the football team had just used their
$200 there might have been a possibility of
having enough for the other three teams, but
the football team used $600 of the $800 in the
treasury and with the fact that lacrosse and
track will probably need more, it simply
meant that one team had to be dropped.
Which one should it be? The Board looked
at it in this light. There was less interest in
baseball than in any of the other sports and
baseball was dropped.
From the Senior class, Mr. Iglehart was the
only man who has been out for the team in
past years and he would be debarred this year.
From the Junior class, Mr. Hardcastle was
the only man out last year. From the Fresh-

for baseball when only five undergrads. were
even out for the team and there are twice that
many out for lacrosse and track? It would
mean that most of the men on the baseball
team would be meds. or grads.
The money paid into the treasury is paid by
the undergrads. and surely it should be used
for their teams as far as possible.
In regard to the football team the only
motion passed was that next year the captain
be an undergraduate. There was no motion
made or passed to debar meds., grads. or any
other department of the University.
The sentiment of the Board was that the
captain be undergrad. a good coach secured,
and everybody who wants to come out for the
team can do so. But the men who practice
faithfully and regularly would not be replaced
on the day before the game by some man who
comes out with a reputation but who has not
trained and who, previous to this, had not
been out for the team. The Board wants to
see every man given a fair show and in the
past the undergrad. were certainly not given
this in football.
Now, if you will pardon it, a few personal
reasons why we should have an undergraduate
football team.
1st—It would save a bill of $190 to $200 a
year for meals.
2nd—The men could get out on the field
at least once a week, which is an essential.
3rd—The men would train which has not
been done by the team in the past two years.

who would fight for all they were worth to
win and not men playing merely for the love
of the game.
5th—The team would be better supported
by the student body and its friends, and the
alumni.
6th—Under new rules the game does not
need so much weight as it needs speed and
head-work, and by having practice on the
field once a week a better team could be
developed than by relying on the medical men
to work in the cage two or three nights a
week.
To summarize the team would be a better

JUNIOR VS. FRESHMAN.
Another class football game has come and
gone and, as is usually the case, the Juniors
gained the victory. The victory was a hard
earned one, and both teams deserve great
credit for their sterling exhibition of hard,
clean football. The victory was won by the
narrow margin of five points, scored in the
latter part of the first half. After a series of
even plays, the ball was in the possession of
the Freshmen on their own 15-yard line; an
attempt to punt was blocked by Tilghman of
the Juniors, and Street '08 fell on the ball on
the Freshmen's 4-yard line. From there, in
three line plunges, the Juniors pushed Bridgman over the line for a touch down. The attempt at goal failed and the half ended soon
after. In the second half the playing was
slightly in favor of the Juniors, but the advantage was very slight. In this half '09
worked the prettiest forward pass that has
been seen around Baltimore this year; Bevan
their end receiving the ball nicely and gaining
about 25 yards on the play.
One of the surprises of the game was the
remarkable strength shown by the '08 line.
The Freshmen were supposed to have a slight
advantage there, but the Junior line played so
well, that they easily offset the advantage the
Freshmen had in Michael, by successfully
breaking three and blocking his punts. For
the juniors Abel at right half played the best
game, closely followed by Chesney and Bridgman. Chesney had the call over Bird '09 in
backing up the line, and was in the main part
responsible for the failure of the Freshmen's
attempted end runs.
Toby Tilghman played well at left tackle,
and it was through him that the Juniors were

able to score. For the Freshmen Gutman
played the best game.
Following the football game came the cane
rush and, contrary to general expectations,
this was won by the Freshmen by 11 hands to
10. This was due partly to the fact that Bird,
president of '09, succeeded in pulling the '08
president, Wegefarth, over his head as the
whistle blew, and partly to the fact that the
Freshmen were more successful in getting
hands on the cane after the time was up.
With all the regard due to those in charge
of affairs, we must say that there should be
some change made in the future, in the manner of running the cane rush, for there was
such confusion and debate in the counting
that it was hard to tell who had a hand on the
cane and who had not. Moreover, the present
generation must be possessed of remarkable
small hands to get 21 good grips an a cane
scarcely longer than 3 feet 6 inches. The
Freshmen won the contest squarely nevertheless, and it will pass on to history as a victory
for '09 by the score of 11 to 10.
Another important event which was noticed
at the game, was the blossoming out of the
1908 class flag. This particular banner is a
wonderful creation of red, white, and what
not, and with the respect due it we are somewhat possessed of the idea that its designer
must have been under the influence of a welsh
rabbit when he produced a design of such
nightmare qualities.

The recent controversy which has arisen among the students as to
the recognition of the baseball team has brought to our mind a question concerning the Athletic Board, that is, what does the Athletic Board really represent? One
hears on all sides statements as to the partiality of the board as to the unfairness and so on
until one wonders how the board ever were elected.

When we acknowledge their election the

question arises as to what consensus of opinion do they follow. Among the list of members
we see that there are senior delegates, junior delegates and a freshman delegate but as far as
can be seen the only thing necessary for their election is that they belong to their respective
classes. Do they then necessarily represent the members of their class. According to the
present system of election we do not think so. The delegates are elected by the members of
the University in toto and it matters little if the class which the delegate is going to represent

To the Editor of the News-Letter:
DEAR SIR.—I was delighted to read, in
your last issue, an article advocating the recognition of the baseball team for this year. This,

shows that the spiritfor baseball has not entirely succumbed, while at the same time it
proves that those who took part in the game
and know most about the matter are eager for
the maintenance of the team, and fully aware
of the fact that it is not only possible to have
one, but that it is the best thing and the only
thing to do.
There are two reasons given for not recognizing the team—namely, lack of interest and
lack of funds.
For anyone to say that there is a lack of interest is as absurd as it would be immaterial
if it were a fact. If there's no interest—make
it. Anyone who was present at the Lehigh
game last year would have been a poor interpreter of human actions if he should not have
seen that the fellows were with the team, and
crazy for victory and delighted when it came.
To tell the truth, I believe there was more interest shown at that game than at any Lacrosse game last year, with the possible exception of;the Swarthmore game, for which I cannot speak as I was not fortunate enough to be
present, being at the time at Charlottesville
where we enjoyed another glorious victory.
But whatever might have been the real feeling in the matter, the fact remains that there
were as many fellows present at the baseball
games, and as much rooting, if not more,
than at the Lacrosse games.
Someone might say: "Oh, yes, when we
have a team, the fellows come out to see the
games, but they are not interested enough to
try for the team, etc., etc." All of which is
again absurd, and contrary to fact. We had
something like fifteen or twenty candidates
last year. Some of these, it is true, were not
up to the standard, but the fact remains that
they had the spirit to come out. What's more,
at least half the fellows are back again, and
there are other good men who said they would
come out this year. All that is needed now,
is a manager to arrange a schedule and to
drum up players, but he's needed immediately.

we had to buy a mitt which cost $5. This is
$47 which will not have to be spent this year.

John's in Baltimore—or rather scheduled the
game there. This year we would have to
play at Annapolis, and would receive $30
guarantee which would more than pay expenses. We could get $40 from Navy, which
much more than pays expenses. West Point
gave us $125 last year, which paid expenses
all but about $10. They were very much
pleased with the game, and asked us to be
sure to come again. I'm certain they would
give a guarantee to cover expenses this year.
University of Virginia gave a guarantee which
paid expenses all but 8 cents.
Certainly, from these few facts it is plain
that the financial difficulty is more of a myth
than a reality. Nor does the fact that the
three games played at home failed to pay expenses, alter the matter. It must be remembered that these games were played—two of
them on Friday, and the other on Saturday
morning. The only other game we had

obtained more glory in Lacrosse, we feel that
the baseball team has done, taking everything
into consideration, as much.
Let us not then stand back and say there
are.too many difficulties to be overcome, but
let us get together, have a team, and make it
successful. The greatest pleasure and glory
is in doing the hard things. The weakest and
meanest thing a man can do, is to give up

licked.
Then here's to the success of baseball at
Hopkins, the game which most men, who
have played all the games and know them,
recognize as, not only one of the most open
and beautiful games to watch, but, with the
possible exception of tennis, as the cleanest
and most sportsmanlike game we have.

Freshmen had in Michael, by successfully
breaking three and blocking his punts. For
the juniors Abel at right half played the best
game, closely followed by Chesney and Bridgman. Chesney had the call over Bird '09 in
backing up the line, and was in the main part
responsible for the failure of the Freshmen's
attempted end runs.
Toby Tilghman played well at left tackle,
and it was through him that the Juniors were

able to score. For the Freshmen Gutman
played the best game.
Following the football game came the cane
rush and, contrary to general expectations,
this was won by the Freshmen by 11 hands to
10. This was due partly to the fact that Bird,
president of '09, succeeded in pulling the '08
president, Wegefarth, over his head as the
whistle blew, and partly to the fact that the
Freshmen were more successful in getting
hands on the cane after the time was up.
With all the regard due to those in charge
of affairs, we must say that there should be
some change made in the future, in the manner of running the cane rush, for there was
such confusion and debate in the counting
that it was hard to tell who had a hand on the
cane and who had not. Moreover, the present
generation must be possessed of remarkable
small hands to get 21 good grips an a cane
scarcely longer than 3 feet 6 inches. The
Freshmen won the contest squarely nevertheless, and it will pass on to history as a victory
for '09 by the score of 11 to 10.
Another important event which was noticed
at the game, was the blossoming out of the
1908 class flag. This particular banner is a
wonderful creation of red, white, and what
not, and with the respect due it we are somewhat possessed of the idea that its designer
must have been under the influence of a welsh
rabbit when he produced a design of such
nightmare qualities.
